content: I've changed "abs( )" to "| |" in Goal section in case that may constitute a spoiler for players who want to use the "abs" function in their code (if the function is available in the programming language they use).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Should be a good Clash of Code task

Mine ruby solution:
a=`sed 1d`.split.map &:to_i
p a.max/a.reduce(:gcd)
Cool problem, but I think the pattern is hard to see. So maybe make it an easy puzzle

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice Clash

You do not respect your constraints. The "not at all cute" test case and validator use particles sizes above 1000. Which is the limit in the constraints.

You can either keep the constraint and allow brute force approach.
Or extend the constraint. In this last case I would go for way bigger number like a million to forbid brute force.
Note that forbidding the brute force may not fit the clash of code format.

I solved first all the test cases using brute force (adding new elements in an actual set one by one). Then (after I saw your solution) I came with a O(n) one liner. 
I am not entirely sure that I would have found this second solution under 5 min. So I am against preventing brute force in this case.

You solution code is invalid.
Let say I have the particles {6, 9}. I can generate the particle 3 and that is all. So the number of particles is 3.
Your code returns 9.

It is doable and could be fun. 

Some points have to be fixed:
- The chosen element are not removed from the array. This was not clear.
- Actually, you are not playing with an array but a set (I can add an infinite amount of 1 in an array, so the answer is always infinite).
- Why 0 is not a valid number? In the example my set is {0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ,6}. You have to specify that the 2 elements are different or accept the 0.

What is the link with particle simulation? A bit of story would be funnier and actually clearer. For example:
In this universe, each "molecule" is represented by a number. 
You can combine two molecules by finding the absolute difference of their numbers. 
Given a infinite amount of starting molecules, how many different molecules are possible?

Thanks for those points, I feel they are very appropriate.

- The chosen elements will not be removed as the process of infinitely applying the operation need to be stoped somewhere, i.e; when the set is completed and no new elements are can be added to the set, this is the insight I wanted the coder to find out so I didn't mention in question, as you said I think mentioning set instead of the array would make a lot more sense
- for my solution, I'm not considering 0 so I will specify the 2 elements are different, I think accepting 0 doesn't make a lot of difference for every case the final set would contain 0

thanks for these details, I didn't figure it out in the first go
I'll change the question accordingly 
by the way, feel free to edit the question if you are interested.

That's true,
I didn't think of that case, let me change the code
yeah I have set the constraints like that so they can approach brute force, I'll change the test case then
thank you so much
What is the difference between `reduce &:gcd` and `reduce :gcd`? What is the necessity of `&`? I have always used with `&` everywhere.

You manage cases where all numbers are multiples of 2 or multiples of the minimum of the array. 
They cannot be all multiple of a number greater than the minimum. But what if they are multiples of a number lower than the minimum?
You made a special case of multiple of 2 but there is all other numbers.

yes, you are right.!
I have observed few more conclusions and it all depends on the greatest common factor of all number in the array

by simulating the particles according to our operation the least possible value is the greatest common factor of all the elements so the total possible particles will be max(array)/gcd

with this conclusion, the code has become much simpler 
checkout the code I have even made few changes in test cases

Exactly :) 
But we use to call it the greatest common divisor (GCD)

There is more efficient ways to compute it. And actually it is part of the math library of python since 3.5. 

The code become:

import math

n = int(input())
particles = set(map(int, input().split()))
print(max(particles)//math.gcd(*particles))


Simple indeed ;) But you have to see the GCD. And both of us missed it at first.

exactly,
once you get the solution it is simple but question is tricky.

now the code is turned out to be simple we can extend this to shortest code mode also
I am OK with that :)

I allowed myself to make some modifications:

- I removed any notion of set or array to let the coder find the insights himself.
- I used particles everywhere, there was particles, elements and integers mixed. It was confusing. There is still a mix between particles and particles sizes but I think it is OK.
- I highlighted "different size" and "absolute difference".
- I capitalized first words of sentences. You don't seems to like capitalized words ;)
thanks for those changes, now it looks great.
